repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Agricultural Productivity
            Improvement ; Northeast Village Development ; Forest
            Concession Management and Control ; and Flood Emergency Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal ratings for the Cambodia
            Agricultural Productivity Improvement; Northeast Village
            Development; Forest Concession Management and Control; and
            Flood Emergency Projects are as follows: the outcome was
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was significant, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some of the lessons learned from the project
            include the following: in the future, the use of learning
            instrument loans (LILs) or any instrument that circumvents
            any of the usual safeguard investigation during preparation
            should be subject not only to the normal tests of
            eligibility, but also the test o f downside risks, be these
            technical or the likelihood of adverse public opinion; where
            the client is not familiar with Bank operations and
            procedures or is confronting serious impediments to its
            ability to act on that knowledge, continuous presence of
            competent Bank representatives is a critical factor in
            moving dialogue and operations forward; when ambiguity or
            disagreements arise in implementation, particularly with the
            evolving focus or importance of an activity, an agreed
            strategy can become an effective management tool;
            institutions generally respond more favorably to moderate or
            gradual change than to radical innovation, particularly when
            power or stature are being threatened; and finally, while
            fiduciary accountability requires correct procedures and
            oversight, the development impact o f the Bank's
            approach to the issue is very much linked to the sensitivity
            with which it introduces the qualities of transparency and
            cost-effectiveness as desirable qualities in procurement transactions.

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is modest; Bank performance
            is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is satisfactory.
            As a Learning and Innovation Loan, the project was intended
            to help develop and test organizational arrangements,
            planning and implementation processes, and capacity building
            programs focused on enabling local institutions to identify,
            plan, implement, monitor and manage local development
            activities, with the intention to extend the application of
            these, once proven effective, under a larger-scale follow-on
            project. To this end, the lessons learned were discussed
            extensively in workshops at the village, provincial and
            national level, documented in project publications and
            widely disseminated. To inform future design, other lessons
            warranting  consideration regard the following: Benefits and
            drawbacks of the LIL instrument, constraints to sustained
            participation; the several constraints to sustained
            participation; the forbearance of the  .existing members of
            the Village Development Committee (VDC) who to their credit,
            continued their community work in the face of the lack of
            other volunteers; the difficulties of VDC participation; and
            the overall funding that constraints, like literacy, limit
            returns to continued participation ;and the dearth of local
            contributions in some impoverished communities and the need
            for flexibility.

5084483.majtheme: Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
Poverty reduction is the central
            objective within the strategic context, and specific goals
            of the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) are supported by
            the Northeast Village Development Project, such as rural
            development and natural resource management enhancement,
            human resources and poverty reduction improvement, and,
            institutional capacity strengthening. The two main
            components of the project consist of: 1) participatory
            planning and investment, which will include those investment
            activities based on, and supported by, the development of
            participatory planning systems. Beginning at the village
            level, with the creation of the Village Development
            Committees (VDC), different local government levels will
            progressively be reached, in a process defined as the Local
            Development Process (LDP). Through this process the project
            will finance the costs of participatory rural appraisals,
            selected on the basis set by the implementation guide
            criteria. Furthermore, the LDP will assist VDCs in
            determining the community's development priorities;
            and, 2) institutional strengthening and project management,
            i.e., the project will provide resources, both at the
            provincial and district/commune/village levels, to carry out
            the establishment of an information systems management;
            conduct participatory evaluation studies of project
            performance and impact; review subproject design and
            construction supervision; and, provide training as needed.
